title: 109_hr2936
content: The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to cover second opinions under the Public Health Service Act. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates group health plans to provide or authorize a second opinion by a qualified healthcare professional when requested by a participant, beneficiary, or enrollee questioning surgical procedures or diagnosis for life-threatening conditions. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to offer a second opinion by a qualified healthcare professional if a participant questions the reasonableness or necessity of recommended surgical procedures, diagnosis for life-threatening conditions, unclear clinical indications, or ineffective treatment plans. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates that if a professional cannot diagnose a condition, the participant can request an additional diagnosis. This can also be requested if the treatment plan is not improving the medical condition within a reasonable time frame, or if there are serious concerns about the initial diagnosis or plan of care. An "appropriately qualified health care professional" is defined as a primary care physician or specialist. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" allows participants to request a second opinion if they have serious concerns about the initial diagnosis or plan of care. An "appropriately qualified health care professional" is defined as a primary care physician or specialist with expertise related to the specific illness. Opinions must be provided in a timely manner. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" allows participants to request a second opinion in an expeditious manner, especially in cases of imminent health threats. Timelines for rendering second opinions should not exceed 72 hours after the plan's receipt of the request. Each plan or issuer must provide timely opinions to ensure maximum function and health outcomes. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates timely second opinions for participants, with timelines not exceeding 72 hours after the request. Plans must provide opinions promptly to ensure maximum health outcomes. If approved, the plan is not liable for costs incurred. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates timely second opinions for participants, with timelines not exceeding 72 hours after the request. If a group health plan approves a second opinion request, the participant is only responsible for applicable copayments. Primary care second opinions must be provided by a qualified health professional of the individual's choice within the same physician organization. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires timely second opinions for participants, with primary care second opinions provided by a qualified health professional within the same physician organization. Specialists can choose any provider within the network of the same specialty, with the plan covering the cost if not within the same organization. The plan or issuer must cover the cost of a second opinion within the same physician organization, beyond copayments. If no participating provider meets the standard, the plan must authorize a second opinion outside the network. Travel ability of the participant is considered in approving second opinions. The issuer must authorize a second opinion from a qualified health professional outside the network, considering the participant's ability to travel. The second opinion provider must provide a consultation report with recommendations, and the plan may authorize additional medical opinions independently. The plan or issuer must authorize a second opinion from a qualified health professional outside the network. If the request is denied, the participant must be notified in writing with reasons for the denial and informed of the right to file a grievance. Services must be obtained from participating providers unless authorized by the plan. The participant, beneficiary, or enrollee must obtain services from participating providers unless authorized by the plan. Referrals may be limited to the plan's network of providers. This section does not apply to health care service plan contracts with preferred provider arrangements that do not limit access to second opinions. The section exempts health care service plan contracts with preferred provider arrangements from limiting access to second opinions. A group health plan must comply with notice requirements under ERISA. Amendments include adding section 2707 to ERISA. Section 2723(c) of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include sections 2704 and 2707. "SEC. 714. COVERAGE OF SECOND OPINIONS." Section 2707 requirements apply to group health plans and insurance coverage. Notice of these requirements must be provided within 60 days of the first plan year they apply. Section 731(c) of the Act is amended to include sections 711 and 714. Section 104(b)(1) requires providing modification details within 60 days of the first plan year. Section 731(c) and 732(a) of the Act are amended to include sections 711 and 714. The table of contents is updated to reflect these changes. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section 9813, which addresses the coverage of second opinions. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section 9813, which addresses the coverage of second opinions under the Public Health Service Act. The provisions of section 2707 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market. Health insurance issuers must comply with notice requirements similar to group health plans. Section 2762(b)(2) is amended to include additional sections. Effective dates apply to group health plans and insurance. The amendments made by subsection (a) apply to group health plans starting in 2006, while subsection (b) applies to individual health insurance coverage. There is an exception for group health plans under collective bargaining agreements. The amendments made by subsection (a) apply to group health plans starting in 2006, while subsection (b) applies to individual health insurance coverage. There is a collective bargaining exception for group health plans. The last collective bargaining agreements related to the plan must terminate by January 1, 2006. Plan amendments made to conform to new requirements do not count as termination. Secretaries of Labor, Treasury, and Health and Human Services must coordinate administration through an interagency memorandum of understanding. The Secretaries of Labor, Treasury, and Health and Human Services must coordinate administration through an interagency memorandum of understanding to ensure regulations, rulings, and interpretations are administered consistently and enforcement efforts are coordinated to avoid duplication.
